Juvenile Hunt Well today my pops and I decided that we were too tired to travel an hour to our hunting lease.. so we just decided that I would go hunt behind our house. The Devil Is Still In Business As you may or may not know, I have been reading the book Fresh Wind, Fresh Fire , and it has been an awesome book. I was reading it today, and something that came across me just really stood out... Here's what it said "About half an hour into the meeting, after we had been worshiping for a while, I said, "There's a girl here who's been brought by some members, and they'd like her to be prayed for; she's hooked on drugs." These members began walking toward the front with a short Hispanic girl. She seemed in a daze---the effect of drugs, I assumed. Her name was Diana. I was standing, as I usually do on Tuesday nights, on the ground level with the people, at the head of the center aisle. All of a sudden, I began to tense up; alarm bells seemed to be going off in my spirit signifying that something was wrong---something was about to happen. I noticed off to my right a visiting evangelist I knew. I said to her, "Amy, it's good to see you here tonight. Would you come help me pray for this young lady?" AS she moved out of her seat, the Holy Spirit came upon her, and she sensed the same anticipation. We were suddenly both on "red alert" for some unknown reason. One of the associate pastors joined us, and we laid hands on Diana and began to pray. "O Jesus, help us," I said quietly. Like a shot, the mention of Jesus' name brought an explosion of rage and screaming. The five-foot-one-inch girl lunged for my throat, throwing back the two friends who had guided her up the aisle. Before I knew what was happening, I had been body-slammed against the front edge of the platform. Diana ripped the collar right off my white shirt as if it were a piece of tissue. A hideous voice from deep inside her began to scream, "You'll never have her! She's ours! Get away from her!" The language then turned obscene. Some of the congregation stood and began to pray aloud. Others gasped. Some covered their eyes. Meanwhile, several deacons jumped up and tried to pull her off of me. Despite her size, she fought all of us with tremendous strength. We finally managed to subdue her. Amy, the evangelist, began to pray fervently. I leaned over the girl to address the spirits: "Shut up! In the name of Jesus Christ, come out of her!" I demanded. Diana's eyes rolled back in her head, and twoce she spit directly into my face, no more than a foot away. The church kept earnestly calling out to God for his help. Clearly, we were not battling some imaginary "spirit of anger" or whatever. This was a classic case of demon possession. Within a few minutes, the girl was set totally free. She stopped cursing; her body relaxed. We relaxed our grip on her, and she gently stood up to raise her hands and begin to praising the Lord. Soon she was singing, with the rest of us, "Oh, the blood of Jesus! It washes white as snow," as tears streamed down her cheeks, ruining her makeup. Diana has been serving the Lord for ten years now in the Brooklyn Tabernacle. Recently she married a young man, and both of them gave strong testimonies of their faith in front of mostly unbelieving relatives. She is a wonderful Christian today who loves the Lord and wants to serve him alone ." Basically all I have to say about that is that... Look what the power of God can do with an ordinary person.

Welcome to Laodicea I was looking back on some old notes I took from when Jay, my youth minister, was preaching one Wednesday night about the church of Laodicea, and I just wanted to comment about something he had to say. He was talking about how God didn't like the fact that the people weren't either hot or cold but lukewarm, and here's what I have to say. Imagine yourself at Madison Square Garden sitting in the front row watching your favorite basketball team. About 8 minutes or so into the game, your losing 28-7. "We're committing foolish turnovers, we're not rebounding aggressively, we're giving up fast breaks." The coach calls a time out and we huddle, one person comments on how cool it is that they are playing in Madison Square Garden, another comments on how good the jerseys look, a third waves to his family, and a fourth runs over to give his girlfriend a kiss on the cheek. What do you think that coach would say? "Hey! Would you guys look at the scoreboard? We're getting killed! This game is going to get away from us if you don't wake up!" As a team we couldn't fantasize or make believe we were doing well. The scoreboard was the signal that we had to change our game plan. The Christian world is not playing as well as we think. We often confuse faith with fantasy. Hebrews 11:6 states that "without faith, it is impossible to please God." So I say to you now. We are deeply in trouble, it is a high time that we wake up and look at the scoreboard! With some exceptions we are like the church at Laodicea. We have so institutionalized Laodicenism that we think its normal to be lukewarm (Rev. 3:15-17). We have profesed our faith to God and accepted him, but we are so overwhelmed by our everyday life that we don't realize that we are drawing away from Christ. So I urge you, wake up, take charge, and come back to Christ.

Calling on God I've always thought that Satan's main strategy with God's people has been to whisper, "Don't call, don't ask, don't depend on God to do great things. You'll get along fine if you just depend on your own cleverness and energy." The truth of the matter is that the devil is not terribly frightened of our human efforts and credentials. But he knows his kingdom will be damaged when we lift up our hearts to God. Listen to David's confident assertion in Psalms 4:3. "Know that the Lord has set apart the godly for himself; the Lord will hear when I call to him ." That was David's whole posture, his instinct, and especially his approach to warfare. it doesn't matter what the Philistine armies have. If we call out to God, he will give us the victory. If we backslide and don't call, then we can be defeated by a tiny army. David is basically saying, "You can chase me, you can persecute me, you can do anything you want... but when I call on God, you're in trouble! The Lord will hear you when I call to him."

Like Lighthouses I was recently listening to a Garth Brooks song, and even though I've heard the song many times, the lyrics have never really caught my attention... until now. In the song it says, "There's a ship out, on the ocean at the mercy of the sea, it's been tossed about, lost and broken, wandering aimlessly." When you think about what that says, what you get is that... we are all like lighthouses, in that, the beam of light is significant to us searching for truth, and the ocean is the world around us, but the storm that stirs up the ocean is like Satan, because he will do whatever it takes for us to not find God. But out there in the ocean a boat lurks, and that small boat out there amongst all the haste is God. Everyday Satan complicates our lives more and more, making the waves larger, and as much as we reject God or don't devote ourselves to him, than the more we hurt him. For some people, they don't see God out there in the stirred up world because of the giant waves Satan has created. But still for some, God is like a large vessel that's about to hit the island. It goes on to say in the song "There's a moment we all come to in our own time and our own space, where all that we've done, we can undo, if our heart's in the right place." What I think that means is that, no matter how much sin we have, if we realize that God is there for us to forgive us then we can make everything better.... Like lighthouses, we are ever searching.

Not my God Well, I was listening to another song and I was thinking about what it really meant (since that seems like that's the one thing I'm good at.) But anyway, I was listening to "Your Not My god" by Keith Urban and this really stuck out to me because it's a lot like out everyday lives. It starts off saying "It's just a piece of paper, it says 'In God We Trust.' A little sure felt good, but a lot was not enough...I thought I had everything, when I held the gold." Sometimes we let so many things control our lives, things like money, being popular, winning things, or looking good, whatever it is, they always end up taking the place of our God. It's pretty obvious in the song that he's trying to say this because he goes onto say, "'Cause you're not my god, and you're not my friend. You're not the one that I will walk with in the end. You're not the truth, you're a temporary shot, you ruin people's lives and you don't give a second thought." This is why I love this song; it speaks so much truth in just a few short lines. I'm not going to recite everything from this song, just because there is so much and that would take a while, so listen to the song and think about what it means, and think about what material things in your life that replace the one and only God. If you realize these things and correct them I guarantee you will get closer and closer to God.

There were times where I was really worshiping and I learned a few things from Greg Pinkner, and there were times where I was distracted by the things around me. But theres just something missing, something that I'm still lacking... and I think its the fact that I just learned things and never really drew closer to God.

Love is patient... I'm not Have you ever liked someone but were too afraid to tell him or her because you didn't know what their initial response would be? Well I've been in this situation for a long time, and I don't think I will ever tell them... I've told them once but I knew what they were going to say, which I wasn't going to like, but oh well. I don't even think I would ever have a chance to be in a loving/Godly relationship with them even though I think we have alot in common spritualy and in general. I was at the mall yesterday with my brother Tyler, and we were just hanging out because he left for Texas today and will be gone for a month... but anyway we were walking around and I was kind of thinking to myself "when will I experience love, and will I know it, what should I do to find the right person" and right as I was thinking this, this guy came up to Tyler and I and gave us a card, when I turned it over I noticed the verse 1 Corinthians 13:4-7 was written out, and the thing that caught my attention was the first 3 words..."Love is patient". So in other words I think God is telling me to calm down and let it happen.
